Authors:
Frazer Midot, Jian Chuan Chai , Sharon Yu Ling Lau, Lulie
Melling, Hun Jiat Tung, Wei Chee Wong
Title:
Genetic Diversity and Demographic History of Ganoderma
boninense in Oil Palm Plantation of Sarawak, Malaysia Inferred from ITS
Regions
Keywords:
Ganoderma boninense, oil palm, phylogenetic relationships,
ITS region
Abstract:
Ganoderma boninense is the major causal agent of oil palm
basal stem rot and is responsible for substantial economic losses to the
Southeast Asian palm oil industry, where Malaysia and Indonesia are the
main producers. Sarawak, being one of the largest palm oil producers in
Malaysia, is also affected by this disease. Phylogenetic analysis
determined that a single species, G. boninense occurred in all sampled
population within Sarawak. Sequence variations in G. boninense internal
transcribed spacers (ITS) were analysed for population structure and
phylogenetic relationships among haplotypes within sampled populations.
The ITS1-5.8S-ITS2 regions of 117 isolates from four population in eight
locations across coastal areas of Sarawak revealed seven haplotypes. The
majority of which comprised of the haplotype designated GbHap1 (81.2%)
and was found throughout all sampled locations. Intra-strain
heterogeneity in ITS sequences has been reported in other Ganoderma
species. Genetic variations in G. boninense were observed mainly in the
ITS1 region with no variation in the 5.8S rDNA region. It was also
revealed that genetic differences was low among all populations analysed
with low haplotype diversity, low polymorphic loci numbers and low
nucleotide diversity within each population. Genetic distance did not
correlate with physical distance. Information obtained through haplotype
analysis of ITS sequences showed slight evidence of a recent demographic
expansion. However, analyses of multiple gene loci and subsequent
resampling is suggested to assist in revealing more information to help
resolve the evolutionary relationships and population expansion aspects
of G. boninense population.
